

Chrissy Gonzalez

MongoDB Support Portal

MongoDB customers are able to request help online, but the user experience is confusing and only available to accounts with paid support subscriptions. From December 2017 to August 2018, I worked on a redesign of the Customer Support portal to make it more intuitive, address known problems, and provide options for all users.

Background

MongoDB's support team hadn’t had a dedicated designer until I joined. The Customer Portal, where customers request help, had a backlog of problems and feature improvements that needed design attention. It was also in need of a visual update.

Competitive Audit

This project, my first introduction to the customer-facing side of our support offering, grew out of a smaller effort to update a small part of the knowledge base. I did a quick survey of the entire Customer Portal as a way to get started, and a few things struck me as odd. First, there was no Help Center or Support Home on the MongoDB marketing site – support was either a paid, signed-in service or else customers had to find MongoDB’s Google Group and Stack Exchange answers on their own. Second, we didn’t try to deflect unnecessary case creation by offering common answers and resources on the support site. Third, searching our JIRA backlog surfaced consistent problems we’d known about for years but hadn’t addressed.

I wanted to make a case for making larger improvements to the Customer Portal, so I looked for examples of great support sites and gathered them into a competitive audit. I tried to focus on companies that sell technical or developer-focused tools, as well as companies known for a great online support experience.

Competitive Support Audit

Sketches and diagrams

At first, I spent a lot of time sorting through the existing portal, in order to reorganize it into something that made a little more sense. I like to begin the actual design process by giving form to what I know and sketching how things might work before I get into design software.

Early sketches and diagrams

First draft

MongoDB has a pretty robust design system for constructing pages and components, which I took advantage of for the first round of wireframes. My goals for the redesign were to fulfill the knowledge base team’s original request while also trying to: a) make the site organization more intuitive, b) clarify email list and team management options, c) provide resources for both paid and community customers, d) align visual style with current branding, and e) take a first pass at letting users self-help. This first version focused on site organization, resources for all, self-help, and the knowledge base.

First draft of the portal redesign

Process and refinements

Since this was a project largely of my own creation, I started by taking the first version and sharing it around to socialize the idea of it, then collecting feedback and starting the process over again. It worked pretty well – at some point, we started discussing new features, like adding MongoDB University activation links or creating an overview of Professional Services appointments, only in terms of the ‘new version’ of the portal.

As for meeting my initial goals, the knowledge base team mainly wanted better text styling, which I handled using the MongoDB documentation style, and search tagging, which will be done by the engineers. Site organization was improved by simplifying the navigation structure and organizing project-level information (projects are a Salesforce constraint) into projects where it made sense. That made it easy to give email lists and teams their own pages, too. I added the Help Center and used it to list all of our documentation, training, and community resources, as well as FAQs. The signed-in home has more browsable self-help content from the knowledge base and University training, if it comes with a user’s subscription. And I imported the CSS from our design system and built static versions of the main pages to make it easier to build in a style consistent with our other products.

As of late August 2018, I’m in the process of testing the redesign with existing users, many of whom are database administrators or architects within large companies, and updating based on their feedback. We hope to release the new version to customers in late fall. There aren’t many defined metrics for success on this project, but we do expect to see a reduction in common problems and an increase in knowledge base engagement. I also think there should be an increase in engagement with training materials and community resources, which would benefit many of our customers, free and paid.

Latest version of the portal redesign
